articles.title: Your Finance Provider: Billing, Contacts, and What to Do if You're Selling or Refinancing
question_aliases: How do I contact my lender?
What happens to my solar loan if I sell my house?
Can I transfer my solar lease to a new buyer?
How do I refinance with solar?

content_chunks.content: Your solar system was financed through one of several providers Venture Home works with. This article explains how to identify your provider, who to contact for billing and account questions, and what steps to take if you're refinancing your home or planning to sell. Your finance provider is listed in the agreement you signed when you went solar. If you're unsure, check any billing statements or emails you received after installation.

If you financed your system with a loan, you own the solar equipment. Your monthly payment goes to your lender. Service, warranties, and system support are handled separately through Venture Home. If you have a lease or PPA, the finance company owns the equipment and handles maintenance, repairs, and monitoring at no additional cost.

articles.title: Sungage Financial
question_aliases: Can I transfer my Sungage loan?
How do I refinance with Sungage?

content_chunks.content: Sungage Financial contact information: Phone: (844) 786-4243. Hours: Monday through Friday 9am-10pm ET, Saturday 10am-7pm ET. Email: CustomerService@SungageFinancial.com. Billing portal: sungage.com

Selling your home: Sungage loans cannot be transferred to a new buyer. The loan must be paid off at closing. Refinancing: Sungage offers options for handling your loan during a refinance — contact them directly to discuss.

articles.title: Dividend Finance

articles.title: Monitoring Your Enphase System
question_aliases: How do I check my Enphase system?
What does normal Enphase production look like?
How do I use the Enphase app?

content_chunks.content: Your Enphase solar system comes with the Enphase App, which gives you a real-time view of your system's performance from your phone. Download the Enphase App from the App Store or Google Play. You'll need to create an Enphase account or log in if one was already set up during installation.

The home screen shows real-time power production, home consumption, and battery status if you have one. The app displays an energy flow diagram showing the relationship between your solar panels, battery, home, and the grid at any given moment.

On a clear day, your production graph should show a smooth bell curve — starting at zero before sunrise, climbing through the morning, peaking in early afternoon, and tapering back to zero by sunset. Shorter curves are normal in winter or on cloudy days.

What you don't want to see: flat lines during daylight hours, sudden drops, or days with zero production. These indicate potential issues. If you see errors or alerts, check our troubleshooting guide or contact Customer Success.

articles.title: Monitoring Your SolarEdge System
question_aliases: How do I check my SolarEdge system?
What does normal SolarEdge production look like?

content_chunks.content: Your SolarEdge system is monitored through the mySolarEdge app, available on the App Store and Google Play. Download the app and log in using your SolarEdge account credentials.

The dashboard shows current power output, today's total energy production, and lifetime generation. You can view daily, weekly, monthly, and yearly production charts. The app also shows individual panel-level data — you can see exactly how each panel is performing.

On sunny days, production should follow a bell curve peaking in early afternoon. All panels should show similar output levels. If one panel is consistently showing significantly lower production, that may indicate an issue.

articles.title: Monitoring Your Tesla Solar System
question_aliases: How do I check my Tesla solar system?
What does normal Tesla production look like?
How do I monitor my Powerwall?

content_chunks.content: Your Tesla solar system is monitored through the Tesla app — the same app used for Tesla vehicles. Download from the App Store or Google Play and log in with your Tesla account credentials.

The Energy tab shows real-time energy flow between solar panels, home consumption, grid usage, and Powerwall status. Tap into each category for more detail and view production history by day, week, month, or year.

If you have a Powerwall, the app gives you full control over settings including backup reserve percentage, operating mode (self-powered, time-based control, or backup-only), and Storm Watch activation.

Solar production should follow a smooth bell curve on sunny days. The energy flow screen shows energy flowing from panels to home and battery during the day, and from battery or grid to home at night.

articles.title: Monitoring Your SunPower System
question_aliases: Which app do I use for SunPower?
How do I check my SunPower system?

content_chunks.content: SunPower customers may use one of three apps depending on system configuration: the SunPower App, the Enphase App, or the SunStrong App. Contact Customer Success if you're unsure which applies to your system.

The SunPower App provides a dashboard showing current production, daily and historical generation, and estimated savings. The Enphase App is used for systems with Enphase microinverters — see our Enphase monitoring guide. The SunStrong App is for newer SunPower systems managed by SunStrong.

Production should follow a bell curve on sunny days — rising in the morning, peaking in early afternoon, and dropping to zero by sunset. Consistent daily production with no gaps during daylight hours indicates a healthy system.

articles.title: System Troubleshooting: Errors, Connectivity, and Breaker Resets
question_aliases: My app shows an error what do I do?
How do I reset my solar system?

content_chunks.content: If your monitoring app is showing an error, your system appears to have stopped producing, or your app has lost connection, there are a few simple things you can check before contacting support. Start by opening your monitoring app and looking for any error alerts or notifications.

Step 1: Check your wifi or cellular connection. All Venture Home monitoring systems communicate over wifi, cellular, or both. If your home wifi is down or your router was recently changed, your system may need to be reconnected. For Enphase, SolarEdge, and Tesla: if you changed your wifi network name or password, contact Customer Success and we can help update your network credentials remotely.

A connectivity issue does not affect your system's production — your panels are still generating power even if the app isn't updating. For SunPower customers with a PV Supervisor: your system uses wifi only and does not have cellular backup. Once wifi is restored, the system should reconnect on its own within a few minutes.

Step 2: Check your breakers. If your app shows an error or your system has stopped producing entirely, a tripped breaker is often the cause. Enphase systems have a dedicated Enphase Combiner or IQ System Controller enclosure — look for any breakers inside. If a breaker is tripped (middle or 'off' position), flip it fully off and then back on.

SolarEdge inverters have two key switches: a red ON/OFF toggle and a black DC disconnect dial. Turn both to off, wait 30 seconds, then turn the DC disconnect back on followed by the red toggle. Tesla systems can often be restarted remotely by our team. SunPower customers should check the main electrical panel for a dedicated solar breaker.

Still seeing an issue? Contact our Customer Success team. Have ready: the error message shown in your app, which system you have (Enphase, Tesla, SolarEdge, or SunPower), and approximately when the issue started. We can review your system's data remotely and determine whether a service visit is needed.

articles.title: My Production Seems Low — What's Going On?
question_aliases: Why is my bill higher than expected?
Is my solar system working properly?

content_chunks.content: If you've noticed a higher-than-expected utility bill or feel like your solar system isn't performing the way it used to, you're not alone. The most common reason customers feel their production is low is a higher utility bill — but these are two different things. Your solar system offsets a portion of your electricity usage, but if your consumption has increased, your bill can rise even when your system is producing normally.

Seasonal changes have a significant impact. Solar production is naturally lower in fall and winter due to shorter days, lower sun angles, and more cloud cover. A system producing 40% less in December than in June is completely normal. Before assuming something is wrong with your system, consider whether anything in your home has changed.

The best way to confirm your system is working is to log into your monitoring app. Look for consistent daily production with no gaps or error alerts. Red flags include days with zero production, sudden drops compared to the same period last year, or error notifications from your inverter.

Contact support if you see: multiple consecutive days of zero production, a significant and unexplained drop compared to the same month last year, error alerts in your monitoring app, or any visible damage to your panels or inverter.

articles.title: What Happens Between Signing and Installation?
question_aliases: How long until my solar is installed?
What is the timeline for solar installation?
When will my solar be installed?
What happens after I sign the contract?

content_chunks.content: After you sign your agreement with Venture Home, there are several steps before your installation day. Most customers find this period to be the longest part of the process — typically around 90 days from signing to installation, though it can vary depending on your town and utility company.

You'll be assigned a Regional Operations Manager and Senior Project Manager who will oversee your project from start to finish. Our engineering team will finalize the custom design for your solar system based on your roof, energy usage, and goals.

Permitting and utility approvals is typically the longest step. Venture Home handles all permitting with your town and the interconnection application with your utility company on your behalf. You don't need to do anything — we manage the paperwork, submissions, and follow-up. Timelines are set by your municipality and utility.

If your neighborhood has a homeowners association, Venture Home will work directly with your HOA to obtain any required approvals. Your project team will keep you informed as key milestones are reached. If you ever want a status update, our Customer Success team is available to help.

articles.title: What to Expect on Installation Day
question_aliases: Do I need to be home for solar installation?
Will my power go out during installation?

content_chunks.content: Installation day is when your solar system goes from a plan to hardware on your roof. Most residential installations are completed in a single day. Larger systems or jobs with complex electrical work may require a second day. Your project coordinator will give you advance notice if your job is expected to run into a second day.

An adult must be present at the home for the duration of the installation. Our crew will need access to the interior of your home, including your electrical panel and attic. Connecting your solar system requires us to shut off power temporarily. If this applies, the outage typically lasts between 30 minutes and two hours.

Before the crew arrives, please ensure there is room for two vans to park near your home. Clear any obstacles blocking access to your electrical panel or attic, and ensure the attic entry is accessible. If you have a gate or locked area, make sure it's unlocked for the day.

Once installation is complete, your system will be fully installed but not yet turned on. Before activation, it needs to pass a municipal inspection and receive Permission to Operate from your utility company. Your crew will walk you through what was installed before they leave.

articles.title: Permission to Operate (PTO) — Why Your System Isn't On Yet
question_aliases: Why isn't my solar system on?
When will my system be turned on?

content_chunks.content: After your solar installation is complete, your system cannot be turned on until your utility company grants Permission to Operate (PTO). This is required approval that allows your system to connect to the grid. The timeline is set by your municipality and utility company, not Venture Home.

The process has two main steps. First, a local inspector must visit your home to approve the installation — typically scheduled within one to four weeks. Once the inspection passes, the inspector issues a certificate of completion and notifies the utility to release the job. This handoff step is outside our control and can occasionally cause delays.

Second, once your utility receives the release, they conduct their own review and issue PTO. This step typically takes an additional one to three weeks. In total, most customers receive PTO within three to five weeks of their completed installation.

During this waiting period, your system is fully installed and ready — it simply cannot be activated until approval is received. You do not need to take any action. Venture Home monitors the status and will notify you as soon as PTO is granted and your system is activated.

Important: You must not turn your solar system on before receiving official Permission to Operate. Activating your system before PTO can result in penalties from your utility and may affect your net metering eligibility. Your inverter is left in standby state specifically to prevent activation until PTO is confirmed.

articles.title: Understanding Net Metering and Your Utility Bill
question_aliases: Why do I still have an electric bill?

content_chunks.content: Net metering is a billing arrangement between you and your utility company. When your solar system produces more electricity than your home is using, the excess power flows back to the grid and your utility credits your account. When your system isn't producing enough — at night, on cloudy days, or during high-consumption periods — you draw from the grid and those credits offset what you owe.

Think of it like a bank account: you deposit energy when you have a surplus and withdraw it when you need it. Most Venture Home customers are on true net metering, where your excess energy is credited at or near the full retail rate of electricity.

Net metering credits roll over from month to month. Your system is designed to overproduce in spring and summer, building up credits that offset your higher-consumption winter months. Some utilities perform an annual true-up where remaining credits are paid out at a lower rate. Connecticut customers use 'netting' instead of net metering — excess generation is compensated as a monetary credit.

You will still receive a monthly electric bill because of fixed charges — customer charges, delivery fees, and distribution charges that cannot be offset by solar credits. Your goal with solar is to significantly reduce your annual electricity costs, not eliminate your bill entirely.

articles.title: How Will Solar Change My Utility Bill?
question_aliases: What will my electric bill be with solar?
Why is my bill higher in winter?
How much will I save with solar?

content_chunks.content: When your system first turns on, your utility bill won't disappear overnight. You'll still receive a monthly bill that covers any electricity your solar system didn't produce, plus fixed charges like customer and delivery fees that cannot be offset by solar.

Monthly solar production is uneven — and that's normal. A system that covers 90% of your annual electricity needs might cover 120% in July and only 50% in December. Your annual offset percentage is calculated across a full year, not every single month.

If your system was activated in fall or winter, your first several months of bills will likely show a higher utility balance than you'll see long-term because your system is running during its lowest-production months. This is completely normal. Once spring and summer arrive, production climbs and you'll accumulate credits that offset winter usage.

Give it a full year before drawing conclusions about your system's performance. Net metering credits carry forward — summer surplus helps offset winter shortfalls. Your goal is significant annual savings, not a zero bill every month.

articles.title: What's Covered Under Warranty?
question_aliases: What does my solar warranty cover?
How long is my solar warranty?
Do I have to pay for repairs?

content_chunks.content: Your solar system is backed by multiple layers of warranty coverage. Venture Home provides a 10-year workmanship warranty on every installation, covering the quality of our installation work including all roof penetrations. If you experience a roof leak or structural issue attributable to our installation, Venture Home will address it at no cost.

Equipment warranties for customer-owned systems: Solar panels carry a 25-year product warranty. Enphase microinverters carry a 25-year warranty. The Enphase IQ Gateway has a 5-year warranty. Tesla Powerwall has a 10-year warranty that includes labor. Tesla solar inverter has a 12.5-year warranty with labor covered.

For lease and PPA customers (TPO): Your finance provider owns the equipment and handles all maintenance, repairs, monitoring, and insurance for the full term of your agreement — typically 25 years. You should never pay out of pocket for a system repair or equipment failure.

articles.title: What If My System Is Damaged?
question_aliases: What if a tree falls on my solar panels?
What if hail damages my panels?
My solar panels are damaged what do I do?

content_chunks.content: Solar systems are built to withstand the elements, but severe weather events — hail, fallen trees, ice storms, high winds — can occasionally cause damage. Do not attempt to inspect, move, or repair any part of your solar system after a weather event. Damaged solar panels or wiring can present electrical hazards even when the system appears off.

Contact Venture Home as soon as you notice or suspect damage. We will dispatch a technician to inspect the system, document the damage thoroughly, and provide you with a formal damage report. This documentation is exactly what your homeowner's insurance company will need to process a claim.

Storm damage to a solar system is typically covered under your homeowner's insurance policy. Use the documentation Venture Home provides to file your claim. For lease and PPA customers, your finance provider carries insurance on the equipment. Contact Venture Home and your finance provider immediately — do not arrange third-party repairs.

articles.title: What Happens If a Panel, Inverter, or Battery Stops Working?
question_aliases: What if my solar equipment breaks?

content_chunks.content: Equipment issues are rare, but they do happen. Contact Venture Home first — you don't need to figure out whether it's a product defect or installation issue, or call the manufacturer directly. We'll diagnose the problem, determine what's covered and by whom, and coordinate the repair.

If the repair falls under Venture Home's workmanship warranty, there is no cost to you. If the issue is an equipment defect covered by the manufacturer's warranty, the equipment itself is always replaced at no cost. Whether labor is covered depends on the manufacturer's warranty terms — some include labor, some cover parts only.

For lease and PPA customers: monitoring, maintenance, and equipment repairs are included in your agreement. Still start by contacting Venture Home — we can help triage and connect you with your provider's service team if needed.

articles.title: How to Reach Us: Make Sure You're Calling the Right Number
question_aliases: What is Venture Home's phone number?
How do I contact Venture Home?
How do I report an issue?

content_chunks.content: Our main customer support line is: 800-203-4158. This reaches our Customer Success team directly — the people who can look up your account, answer questions, schedule service visits, and help with anything post-installation.

Other ways to reach us: Venture Home App (fastest way — submit a message or service request directly), Webchat on our website for real-time support during business hours, or email through your account.

Our team works hard to respond quickly. If you haven't heard back within one business day, try a second channel — occasionally messages get missed, and we'd rather you reach out again than wait. The Venture Home app and main phone line are the most reliable ways to get a fast response.

articles.title: How Do I Complete My REC Registration?
question_aliases: I got an email about RECs what do I do?
How do I register for solar credits?

content_chunks.content: Your solar system is eligible to generate Renewable Energy Credits (RECs) for the clean energy it produces. Venture Home handles registration on your behalf — you don't need to initiate anything. However, at a certain point we need a few things from you directly: identity verification, account setup, or a signature confirming participation. That's what the email is asking you to do.

The email will come from your state's registry or program administrator — not always from Venture Home directly. This is normal. Complete your portion promptly, as RECs accrue from the date of registration, not from installation. Delays mean credits you could have earned are not being earned.

If your system has been live and you haven't received a registration email, contact Customer Success and we'll look into the status. Registrations can often be backdated, so credits from before registration may still be claimable.

articles.title: Connecticut Solar Incentives
question_aliases: What solar incentives are available in Connecticut?

content_chunks.content:
Connecticut
Incentive
Key Details
Energy Storage Solutions (ESS)
CT Green Bank battery incentive: upfront + performance payments
Property Tax Exemption
Solar fully exempt from property tax increase — automatic
Sales Tax Exemption
Solar equipment exempt from 6.35% CT sales tax
Energy Storage Solutions Program (CT Green Bank)
Connecticut's Energy Storage Solutions (ESS) program, administered by the CT Green Bank along with Eversource and United Illuminating, provides incentives for homeowners who install battery storage systems. The program has two components:
Upfront incentive: A one-time payment based on the storage system's capacity (kWh). Standard residential systems can receive up to $16,000, paid through your installer within approximately 8 weeks of project approval. Low-income customers and those in underserved communities may qualify for higher incentive levels.
Performance incentive: Ongoing payments for up to 10 years based on how much energy your battery contributes to the grid during active dispatch events called by Eversource or UI — typically a few hours on high-demand summer and winter days. Payments are made twice per year.
Program change effective April 1, 2026: PURA approved a new performance-based framework for new enrollments. Passive dispatch (automatic summer pre-programming) has been phased out for new customers. New participants enroll under active dispatch with a smaller enrollment incentive and higher ongoing performance payments over 10 years.
If you are considering adding a battery to your Connecticut home, contact your Venture Home project manager to get the current incentive rates and available capacity — blocks are filled on a first-come, first-served basis.
Your battery must be installed by a participating contractor registered with the CT Green Bank. Venture Home handles the ESS application on your behalf.
Learn more: energystoragect.com
Property Tax Exemption
Connecticut requires that all passive or active solar heating systems and geothermal energy resources be fully exempt from property taxes statewide (CGS § 12-81(57)). Your solar installation will not increase your property tax assessment. No application is required.
Sales Tax Exemption
Connecticut exempts solar panel systems, battery storage, inverters, mounting equipment, and installation labor from the 6.35% state sales and use tax. The exemption is automatic at point of purchase — on a typical $20,000 system, this saves approximately $1,300.

articles.title: Connecticut Utility Guide
question_aliases: How does net metering work in Connecticut?
What is the Solar Production Charge in CT?

content_chunks.content:
Connecticut Utility Guide
Net Metering Under the Residential Renewable Energy Solutions (RRES) Program
Key Takeaways
1-to-1 net metering under the Netting Tariff
A Solar Production Charge applies to all solar electricity generated — the rate depends on when your RRES application was submitted
Connecticut Energy Storage Solutions (ESS) program offers meaningful battery incentives
Utilities: Eversource Energy and United Illuminating (UI)
Net Metering Policy
Connecticut's current solar program, Residential Renewable Energy Solutions (RRES), offers two options: the Netting Tariff and Buy-All. Nearly all Venture Home customers are on the Netting Tariff.
Netting Tariff
The Netting Tariff is 1-to-1 net metering: every kilowatt-hour (kWh) your solar system exports to the grid is credited against what you consume from the grid at the same retail rate. There is no annual true-up — excess credits roll forward month to month and year to year with no expiration.
Solar Production Charge (Solar Energy Adjustment)
The key difference from older net metering programs is the Solar Production Charge, called the Solar Energy Adjustment on Eversource bills. This charge is based on your system's total solar production, measured by a production meter. The rate you pay depends on the year your RRES application was submitted to the utility — and it's locked in for 20 years.
Year Application Submitted
Solar Production Charge Rate
2026
$0.0402/kWh produced
2025
$0.005/kWh produced
2024
No charge
2022–2023 (Eversource)
$0.03/kWh credit (not a charge)
Example: A system producing 600 kWh in a month with a 2026 application date would be charged approximately $24 that month in Solar Production Charge — in addition to any remaining grid usage charges.
Monthly Bill
Your bill will typically include:
Fixed monthly charge ($9–$13)
Solar Production Charge / Solar Energy Adjustment (based on total production)
Delivery charges if you consumed more from the grid than you produced
Net Supply Credit if you produced more than you consumed (offsets all charges including fixed and production charges, making a $0 bill possible)
Many Connecticut solar customers generate excess credits from spring through fall, then draw them down in winter. This is expected and normal.
Energy Storage Incentives (ESS Program)
The Connecticut Energy Storage Solutions (ESS) Program, administered by the Connecticut Green Bank in partnership with Eversource and UI, offers two separate incentive tracks for battery customers.
Passive Dispatch — Upfront Incentive
Customers receive an upfront discount for agreeing to 10 years of mandatory summer participation. The battery is automatically discharged on scheduled weekday events June–August, 5–8 PM. Current incentive rate: $212.50/kWh installed capacity (standard customers, as of late 2025).
Example: 13.5 kWh Powerwall 3 = approximately $2,868 upfront
Participation is mandatory once enrolled — clawback penalties apply for underperformance
Active Dispatch — Performance-Based Incentive
Customers are paid twice annually by the utility based on average kW performance during optional dispatch events (up to ~60 summer, ~5 winter events). No upfront discount.
Year 1–5: $200/kW summer + $25/kW winter
Year 6–10: $115/kW summer + $15/kW winter
Example: 3 kW average performance = $675/year in years 1–5
Customers can enroll in both Passive and Active, Active only, or neither. Venture Home customers can discuss enrollment options with our team.
Program website: energystoragect.com
Maine Utility Guide
1-to-1 Net Energy Billing (Full-Service Customers)
Key Takeaways
1-to-1 net metering (called Net Energy Billing in Maine)
Excess credits roll forward for 12 months, then expire
If you receive supply from a Competitive Electric Provider (CEP) via a separate bill, your supply charges may not be credited — return to full utility service
Utilities: Central Maine Power (CMP) and Versant Power
Net Metering Policy
Maine's program is officially called Net Energy Billing — Kilowatt-Hour Credit. Central Maine Power (CMP) and Versant Power are required under Maine Public Utilities Chapter 313 rules to offer 1-to-1 net metering to solar customers who receive full-service (both supply and distribution) from the utility.
Net metering works by subtracting your solar production from your grid consumption in the same monthly billing cycle at the full retail rate. Each kWh you export offsets one kWh you consume. Any excess credits roll forward month to month for up to 12 months. Unused credits after 12 months expire — there is no cash payout.
Fixed Charges
Even with a solar system sized to cover 100% of your usage, you will still receive a utility bill. Fixed customer charges ($24–$28/month) cover grid infrastructure costs and cannot be offset by solar credits. These are charged regardless of consumption.
Competitive Electric Providers — Important Warning
Maine allows customers to choose their electricity supply from a Competitive Electric Provider (CEP) separate from CMP or Versant. If you receive two separate bills — one from your distribution utility and one from your CEP — your supply charges may not be credited under net metering.
If this applies to you, we strongly recommend switching back to full utility service (supply + distribution from CMP or Versant) to ensure you receive full 1-to-1 net metering benefits. Contact your utility to make this change.
CMP Net Energy Billing: cmpco.com — search "Net Energy Billing"
Versant Power: versantpower.com — search "Net Energy Billing"
RECs and Additional Incentives
Maine solar customers on customer-owned systems are eligible for Class 1 NEPOOL-GIS RECs. Venture Home handles registration for all eligible customers. See the REC registration article for details on how this works and what action you need to take.
Massachusetts Utility Guide
1-to-1 Net Metering + Class 1 RECs
Key Takeaways
1-to-1 net metering — excess credits roll forward indefinitely
Customer-owned systems (cash/loan/Participate Energy): enrolled in Net Metering + Class 1 NEPOOL-GIS RECs
State income tax credit: 15% of system cost up to $1,000 (Form Schedule SC)
Sales and property tax exemptions apply
TPO customers (lease/PPA): enrolled in Net Metering only
Utilities: Eversource, National Grid, Unitil
Net Metering Policy
All three major Massachusetts investor-owned utilities — Eversource, National Grid, and Unitil — offer full 1-to-1 net metering for residential solar systems up to 25 kW AC (limit raised from 10 kW in February 2025).
Each kWh your system exports to the grid is credited against future consumption at the full retail rate. Credits roll forward indefinitely — there is no expiration and no annual true-up cash-out. You simply draw them down when consumption exceeds production (evenings, winter months).
You will still receive a monthly utility bill to cover fixed customer charges ($10–$15/month) that cannot be offset by solar. These are normal and expected.
What Venture Home Enrolls You In
Venture Home enrolls Massachusetts customers in the programs appropriate for their system type:
Customer-owned systems (cash, loan, or Participate Energy financing): Net Metering + Class 1 NEPOOL-GIS RECs. You receive retail-rate bill credits for your solar production and earn Class 1 RECs for every 1,000 kWh produced, which are sold on your behalf.
TPO customers (lease or PPA, including SunStrong and Palmetto): Net Metering only. Your finance provider retains the REC rights as the system owner.
No action is required from you for either enrollment — Venture Home handles registration. If you receive an email from NEPOOL-GIS or the program registry asking you to verify your identity, complete it promptly. RECs accrue from your registration date, so delays mean lost credits.
State Tax Credit
Massachusetts offers a state income tax credit equal to 15% of qualified solar equipment costs, up to a maximum of $1,000. File Schedule SC with your state tax return. If you don't have sufficient tax liability in year one, the credit can carry forward up to 5 years. Consult a tax professional for guidance on your specific situation.
Tax Exemptions
Sales tax exemption: Solar equipment is fully exempt from Massachusetts 6.25% sales tax
Property tax exemption: Solar installations are exempt from property tax assessment for 20 years
Battery Incentives — ConnectedSolutions
Massachusetts battery customers served by Eversource, National Grid, or Unitil are eligible for ConnectedSolutions, a demand response program that pays you to reduce grid draw during peak summer periods. Enrollment is voluntary and does not meaningfully reduce your backup capability. Ask our team about current incentive rates and enrollment when you order a battery.
Note on SREC programs: Massachusetts SREC-I and SREC-II are closed to new enrollment. Customer-owned systems are enrolled in Class 1 NEPOOL-GIS RECs. TPO customers do not receive REC income — those rights belong to the system owner.
New Hampshire Utility Guide
Alternative Net Metering (Monthly Netting with Reduced Rollover Rate)
Key Takeaways
Monthly netting at nearly full retail rate for production consumed in the same billing period
Excess monthly production credited at a reduced rate (supply + transmission + 25% of distribution)
No annual true-up — credits roll forward indefinitely
Third-party electric suppliers are not required to provide net metering credits
Utilities: Eversource Energy NH, Unitil, Liberty Utilities
Alternative Net Metering 2.0
New Hampshire's current program, in place since 2017, is the Alternative Net Metering Tariff. It works in two stages within each monthly billing cycle.
Monthly Netting (Within the Same Billing Period)
Solar production that offsets grid consumption in the same month nets nearly 1-to-1. You only pay a small non-bypassable charge of 1–2 cents per kWh on the portion offset — these support public benefit programs and cannot be avoided.
Example: If you use 700 kWh from the grid and produce 700 kWh of solar, you pay only $7–$14 in non-bypassable charges plus your fixed customer charge ($14–$20/month).
Monthly Excess Production (Rollover Credits)
If your solar production exceeds your consumption in a month, the surplus is credited at a reduced rate — the sum of the Default Energy Service (supply) charge, Transmission charge, and 25% of the Distribution charge. This is meaningfully less than the full retail rate.
Example: If you produce 700 kWh but only use 500 kWh, the first 500 net at nearly retail. The excess 200 kWh rolls over at the reduced rate. These credits roll forward indefinitely with no expiration.
In practice, for a system sized to 100% of your annual usage, only about 10% of annual production is estimated to receive the lower rollover credit rate. The vast majority of production nets at the higher in-period rate.
Competitive Electric Suppliers — Important Warning
New Hampshire utilities are not required to provide net metering credits for customers who receive electricity supply from a Competitive Electric Supplier. If you switched your supply to a third-party provider, your solar credits may not apply to those supply charges.
If this applies to you, contact your utility to return to standard full-service electricity to ensure your system provides full net metering value.
RECs
New Hampshire solar customers are eligible for Class 1 NEPOOL-GIS RECs. Venture Home handles registration. See the REC registration article for details.

articles.title: Maine Solar Incentives
question_aliases: What solar incentives are available in Maine?

content_chunks.content:
Maine
Incentive
Key Details
Property Tax Exemption
Full exemption on renewable energy equipment — apply by April 1
Sales Tax Exemption
Solar equipment exempt from 5.5% Maine sales tax
No State Solar Tax Credit
Maine does not offer a state income tax credit for solar
Solar Property Tax Exemption
Maine exempts renewable energy equipment — including solar arrays, inverters, and paired battery storage — from property tax assessment. The exemption was established by LD 1711 (2019) and applies to all residential solar installations connected to the grid or used for on-site consumption.
The exemption applies to the full value of the qualifying solar and storage equipment, and there is no time limit on how long it lasts.
How to apply: Submit the Renewable Energy Investment Exemption Application to your local town Assessor's Office by April 1 of the first year you want the exemption to take effect. Once granted, you do not need to reapply annually unless you add new equipment.
Contact your town or city Assessor's Office for the application form, or ask your Venture Home project manager for assistance.
Sales Tax Exemption
Maine does not charge sales tax on solar energy equipment purchases. The 5.5% state sales tax is automatically waived for solar panel systems, inverters, racking, and related components. No action is required.

articles.title: Massachusetts Solar Incentives
question_aliases: What solar incentives are available in Massachusetts?

content_chunks.content:
Massachusetts
Incentive
Key Details
State Tax Credit
15% of system cost, up to $1,000 (Schedule EC)
Class 1 RECs
Enrolled by Venture Home for customer-owned systems
Property Tax Exemption
100% exemption on solar equipment value for 20 years
Sales Tax Exemption
100% — no sales tax on solar equipment or installation
Massachusetts State Income Tax Credit — Schedule EC
Massachusetts offers a state income tax credit worth 15% of the total net cost of your solar energy system, up to a maximum of $1,000. This credit directly reduces your Massachusetts state income tax liability.
If you cannot use the full credit in the year of installation, the unused portion can be carried forward to future tax years.
Owner-only benefit: This credit applies to customer-owned systems (cash or loan purchases) only. TPO customers under a lease or PPA are not eligible.
To claim: File Schedule EC with your Massachusetts state income tax return (Form 1 or 1-NR/PY) for the year your system is placed in service.
Schedule EC form and instructions: mass.gov — Schedule EC
Class 1 NEPOOL-GIS Renewable Energy Credits (RECs)
Customer-owned systems in Massachusetts earn Class 1 RECs through NEPOOL-GIS (the regional grid's tracking system). Venture Home handles registration on your behalf. RECs are generated monthly based on your system's actual electricity production — 1 REC per 1 MWh produced.
For customers financing through Participate Energy (our managed credit program), RECs are sold on your behalf and the proceeds offset your system cost. For cash/loan customers, Venture Home enrolls your system and you retain the RECs or can elect to sell them.
TPO note: If your system is financed through a SunStrong or Palmetto lease/PPA, the financing provider retains ownership of the RECs. Venture Home cannot enroll TPO systems for REC ownership.
Property Tax Exemption
Massachusetts provides a 20-year property tax exemption for the value added to your home by a solar energy system. Even though solar panels can increase your property's market value, that additional value is fully excluded from your property tax assessment for 20 years after installation.
There is no separate application required in most municipalities — the exemption is applied automatically at assessment. Confirm with your local assessor's office. Statutory reference: M.G.L. ch. 59 § 5 (45, 45A).
Sales Tax Exemption
All solar energy equipment and installation labor in Massachusetts is exempt from the 6.25% state sales tax. This exemption is applied at the point of sale — no action is required on your part. On a $20,000 system, this represents approximately $1,250 in instant savings.

articles.title: New Hampshire Solar Incentives
question_aliases: What solar incentives are available in New Hampshire?

content_chunks.content:
New Hampshire
Incentive
Key Details
Property Tax Exemption
Municipality-adopted; up to 100% of solar equipment value (Form PA-29)
No State Income Tax
No state income tax — no state solar tax credit applies
No Sales Tax
No general sales tax in NH — automatic savings on equipment
Solar Property Tax Exemption (Form PA-29)
New Hampshire allows municipalities to adopt a solar energy systems property tax exemption under RSA 72:61-62. The majority of NH cities and towns have adopted this exemption — it excludes the full assessed value of your solar equipment (panels, inverters, and for municipalities that re-adopted after January 1, 2020, battery storage too) from your property tax assessment.
The exemption amount and eligibility varies by municipality, but many offer a 100% exemption of equipment value.
How to apply: File Form PA-29 (Permanent Application for Property Tax Credits/Exemptions) with your local Assessor's Office by April 15 of the first year you want the exemption. You only need to file once — it renews automatically.
Form PA-29: Available at your local town/city Assessor's Office or at 
revenue.nh.gov — Form PA-29
Note: To confirm your municipality has adopted the exemption and the specific amount offered, contact your local Assessor's Office. Not all NH towns participate, though the vast majority of major cities do (Concord, Nashua, Portsmouth, Dover, and others all offer it).
No State Sales or Income Tax
New Hampshire has no general sales tax, so you automatically save on the purchase of solar equipment without needing to take any action. There is also no state income tax in New Hampshire, so there is no state-level solar tax credit.

articles.title: New Jersey Solar Incentives
question_aliases: What solar incentives are available in New Jersey?

content_chunks.content:
New Jersey
Incentive
Key Details
SREC-II (SuSI Program)
$85 fixed per MWh for 15 years — enrolled by Venture Home
Property Tax Exemption
100% exemption — solar added value fully excluded
Sales Tax Exemption
100% — no sales tax on solar equipment
SREC-II — Successor Solar Incentive (SuSI) Program
New Jersey has one of the most lucrative solar incentive programs in the country. Under the SuSI program's Administratively Determined Incentive (ADI) track, residential solar owners earn SREC-II certificates that are redeemed for a fixed, guaranteed payment:
Residential rate: $85 per SREC-II
1 SREC-II = 1 MWh (1,000 kWh) of solar electricity generated
Payments guaranteed for 15 years from your interconnection date
A typical 7 kW system generating ~8 MWh/year earns approximately $680/year, or over $10,000 across the 15-year period
SREC-IIs are separate from your net metering credits — you earn both. Venture Home registers your system with the New Jersey Clean Energy Program (NJCEP) and the PJM-EIS GATS tracking system on your behalf. Payments are made through InClime, the SREC-II administrator, once your system is certified.
Rate review: NJBPU periodically reviews SREC-II incentive levels. Residential systems that receive conditional approval before a rate change lock in the $85 rate for their full 15 years. Ask your project manager about timing.
NJCEP SuSI Program: njcleanenergy.com/susi
Property Tax Exemption
New Jersey law exempts the added value of solar installations from local property taxes. Your solar system increases your home's market value, but that increase is fully excluded from your property tax assessment. With New Jersey's average effective property tax rate of approximately 2.3%, this saves the typical homeowner around $1,000 per year on property taxes.
To ensure the exemption is properly applied, contact your local property tax assessor after installation and confirm your solar system certification is on file.
Sales Tax Exemption
New Jersey provides a complete exemption from state sales tax for all solar energy equipment, including panels, inverters, mounting hardware, and battery storage. This is applied automatically at the point of sale — no application needed.

articles.title: New Jersey Utility Guide
question_aliases: How does net metering work in New Jersey?

content_chunks.content:
New Jersey Utility Guide
1-to-1 Net Metering with Annual True-Up and TREC Incentive
Key Takeaways
1-to-1 net metering — credits roll month to month indefinitely
Annual true-up: unused credits paid out at low wholesale rate (~3–5¢/kWh) on your Anniversary Month
You can change your Anniversary Month once — February is usually best
TRECs (Transition Renewable Energy Certificates) provide ongoing per-kWh incentive income
Utilities: PSE&G, JCP&L, Atlantic City Electric, Rockland Electric
Net Metering Policy
New Jersey requires all major utilities to provide 1-to-1 net metering regardless of whether you use the utility's supply service or a third-party supplier. Each kWh your solar system produces first powers your home; any excess exported to the grid earns a kWh credit that can be used in future months.
Anniversary Month and Annual True-Up
Net metering credits roll forward in a "NEM bank" indefinitely throughout the year — but once a year on your Anniversary Month, the bank is reset. Any credits remaining at that point are paid out at a low wholesale rate (typically 3–5 cents per kWh), not the full retail rate.
Your Anniversary Month defaults to approximately 1–2 months after your system's Permission to Operate date. You may change it one time by contacting your utility.
Our recommendation: February is typically the best Anniversary Month for New Jersey homeowners. It gives your system time to accumulate summer and fall credits and then draw them down through the winter before the account resets. A summer Anniversary Month would cause you to give back valuable credits at a fraction of their worth.
Note: watch your bills for at least one full 12-month cycle before requesting a change. The utility only allows one change — make sure you've seen how your credits actually accumulate before deciding.
PSE&G guidance: "The best month for your Anniversary True Up is the month before you begin to accumulate the most electricity credits."
Time of Use Rates — Not Recommended
New Jersey's net metering program is not well-suited to Time of Use (TOU) rate plans. Under TOU, each time period (on-peak, off-peak) has a separate NEM bank, and credits earned in one period cannot offset charges in another. This typically results in large on-peak credit balances while paying full price for off-peak consumption. We recommend staying on a standard rate plan.
TREC Program
New Jersey's Transition Renewable Energy Certificate (TREC) program pays customer-owned solar systems a fixed per-kWh incentive for electricity produced. TRECs are registered through the NJ Clean Energy Program.
Venture Home handles TREC enrollment for all eligible customer-owned systems. If you haven't received enrollment information, contact our team.
New York Utility Guide
1-to-1 Net Metering with Customer Benefit Contribution Charge + NYS Solar Tax Credit
Key Takeaways
1-to-1 net metering — credits roll forward for up to 20 years with no annual expiration
Customer Benefit Contribution (CBC) charge applies monthly for systems installed after 2021, based on system size in DC kW
NY State Solar & Storage Tax Credit: 25% of qualified costs up to $5,000 (Form IT-255) — eligible even for leased systems
Battery incentive available through Con Edison DLM Program
Utilities: Con Edison, National Grid NY, Central Hudson, PSEG Long Island, NYSEG, RG&E, Orange & Rockland
Net Metering Policy
New York requires all utilities to provide 1-to-1 net metering. Each kWh exported earns a credit that offsets future consumption at the full retail rate. Excess credits roll forward for up to 20 years — there is no annual true-up or cash-out for most customers.
Third-party electricity suppliers in New York are required to credit supply charges 1-to-1 as well, so switching suppliers does not jeopardize your net metering.
Customer Benefit Contribution (CBC) Charge
For systems installed after 2021, a monthly Customer Benefit Contribution charge applies. This charge is based on your solar system's nameplate DC capacity (in kW), not your production or consumption.
Utility
2026 CBC Rate (per kW DC per month)
Con Edison
$1.29/kW
National Grid
$0.97/kW
Central Hudson
$1.67/kW
PSEG Long Island
$1.13/kW
NYSEG
$1.19/kW
RG&E
$1.31/kW
Orange & Rockland
$1.00/kW
Example: An 8 kW DC system served by National Grid would pay $7.76/month in CBC, in addition to the standard Basic Service Charge ($16–$24/month). This is partially or fully offset by your net metering credits in most months.
NYS Solar & Storage Tax Credit
New York residents who install solar on their primary residence may be eligible for the NYS Solar Tax Credit, worth 25% of qualified solar equipment costs up to a maximum of $5,000. This credit is available for purchased systems and for leased systems (credits are calculated based on annual lease payments).
File Form IT-255 with your New York State personal income tax return
Credit can carry forward up to 5 years if you don't have sufficient tax liability in year one
For leased systems: you claim 100% of your annual lease payments each year until the $5,000 total cap is reached
Consult a tax professional to confirm eligibility and how to apply based on your specific situation. We cannot provide tax advice.
Battery Incentives — Con Edison DLM Program
Con Edison customers with battery storage can enroll in the Distributed Load Management (DLM) program, which pays for battery dispatch during peak grid demand. Contact our team or check Con Edison's website for current enrollment and incentive details.

articles.title: New York Solar Incentives
question_aliases: What solar incentives are available in New York?

content_chunks.content:
New York
Incentive
Key Details
State Tax Credit
25% of system cost, up to $5,000 (Form IT-255)
NYSERDA Battery Incentive
Upfront $/kWh incentive for home battery storage
NYC Property Tax Abatement
30% of system cost over 4 years (Form PTA-4) — NYC only
Statewide Property Tax Exemption
Solar added value exempt statewide (NY RPT Law § 487)
Sales Tax Exemption
Solar equipment exempt from NY sales tax
New York State Income Tax Credit — Form IT-255
New York offers a state income tax credit worth 25% of the cost of your solar energy system, up to a maximum of $5,000. The credit is non-refundable — it can only offset your existing New York State income tax liability. If the full credit cannot be used in the year of installation, unused amounts can be carried forward for up to five tax years.
Good news for TPO customers: Unlike most state solar tax credits, New York's IT-255 credit may be claimed by homeowners who have solar installed under a lease or PPA on their primary residence, even though they do not own the system. Confirm your eligibility with a tax professional.
To claim: Complete Form IT-255 and attach it to your New York State income tax return for the year your system is placed in service.
Form IT-255 and instructions: tax.ny.gov
NYSERDA Residential Energy Storage Incentive
New York State, through NYSERDA, offers upfront cash incentives for homeowners who install battery storage systems. Incentive levels are structured as $/kWh of installed capacity and vary by utility territory and available block funding:
Rest of State (most Venture Home customers): approximately $200/kWh as of 2025
Con Edison territory (NYC and Westchester): approximately $250/kWh
Incentives are paid directly to your installing contractor (Venture Home) and reflected in your project pricing. Available capacity is funded in megawatt-hour blocks that fill on a first-come, first-served basis.
Note: Long Island (PSEG LI territory) has separate incentives through PSEG Long Island, not NYSERDA directly. Ask your project manager about current rates in your territory.
NYSERDA Energy Storage Program: nyserda.ny.gov/energystorage
NYC Solar Property Tax Abatement (Form PTA-4) — New York City Only
New York City property owners who install solar (and/or battery storage) are eligible for the Solar Electric Generating Systems (SEGS) Tax Abatement — one of the most generous local solar incentives in the country. Key details:
Value: 30% of total eligible solar and battery installation costs, applied over 4 consecutive years at 7.5% per year
Annual cap: $62,500 per year (or your actual property tax liability, whichever is lower)
Eligible properties: Tax Class 1, 2, and 4 NYC properties through December 31, 2034
Applies to both solar panels and battery storage installed simultaneously
How to apply: Form PTA-4 must be filed with the NYC Department of Buildings. Venture Home files on your behalf during the permitting process. Deadline: March 15 each year for the abatement to take effect in the same calendar year (NYC fiscal year runs July 1 – June 30). Applications submitted after March 15 take effect the following July.
Example: A $30,000 system earns $9,000 total over 4 years ($2,250/year) in property tax reductions.
NYC DOB Solar FAQ: nyc.gov/site/buildings/codes/solar-faq.page
Statewide Property Tax Exemption
New York State law (Real Property Tax Law § 487) exempts the added value of solar, wind, and other renewable energy systems from property tax assessments statewide. Your solar installation may increase your home's market value — that increase will not raise your property taxes. This exemption is automatic statewide and does not require a separate application. Note: In NYC, the property tax abatement (above) is the applicable benefit and cannot be combined with the statewide exemption.
Sales Tax Exemption
Solar energy equipment and installation services are exempt from New York State and local sales and use tax. No action required — the exemption is applied automatically at the point of purchase.

New York Utility Guide
1-to-1 Net Metering with Customer Benefit Contribution Charge + NYS Solar Tax Credit

Net Metering Policy

Third-party electricity suppliers in New York are required to credit supply charges 1-to-1 as well, so switching suppliers does not jeopardize your net metering.

For systems installed after 2021, a monthly Customer Benefit Contribution charge applies. This charge is based on your solar system's nameplate DC capacity (in kW), not your production or consumption.

articles.title: Pennsylvania Solar Incentives
question_aliases: What solar incentives are available in Pennsylvania?

content_chunks.content:
Pennsylvania
Incentive
Key Details
PA SREC (AEC) Market
Earn and sell SRECs on the PA market — prices fluctuate
Property Tax
No formal exemption — solar may not materially affect assessments
No State Tax Credit
Pennsylvania does not offer a state income tax credit for solar
Pennsylvania Alternative Energy Credits (SRECs)
Pennsylvania participates in a Solar Renewable Energy Certificate (SREC) market — called Alternative Energy Credits (AECs) in Pennsylvania. Your solar system earns one AEC per MWh of electricity produced, and those certificates can be sold to utilities and electricity suppliers who need them to meet Pennsylvania's Alternative Energy Portfolio Standard (AEPS).
Unlike New Jersey's fixed SREC-II program, Pennsylvania AEC prices fluctuate with market supply and demand. Delaware homeowners can also access the PA SREC market.
Delaware access: Delaware does not have its own SREC market but Delaware solar owners can register their systems to participate in the Pennsylvania AEC market. Venture Home can assist with registration for Delaware customers.
Venture Home registers your PA system in the PJM-EIS GATS tracking system so your AECs are created and available for sale. You can sell through a broker or aggregator to utilities. Ask your project manager about current market pricing and your options for monetizing PA SRECs.
Property Tax
Pennsylvania does not have a formal statewide property tax exemption for solar. However, because PA property tax assessments are based on property values as of January 1 of the prior year, and reassessments are not triggered automatically, many homeowners find that their solar installation does not immediately or materially affect their property tax bill. This can vary by county — consult your local assessor or a tax professional for your specific situation.

articles.title: Pennsylvania Utility Guide
question_aliases: How does net metering work in Pennsylvania?

content_chunks.content:
Pennsylvania Utility Guide
1-to-1 Net Metering with Annual Cash-Out in May
Key Takeaways
1-to-1 net metering — credits roll forward month to month
Annual cash-out: after the May billing cycle, utilities pay out any remaining credits at the "Price to Compare" (~half retail rate)
Third-party electric suppliers are not required to provide net metering credits
SRECs available via PJM-GATS market
Utilities: PPL Electric, PECO Energy, Duquesne Light, West Penn Power
Net Metering Policy
Pennsylvania requires major utilities to provide 1-to-1 net metering for full-service customers (those receiving both supply and distribution from the same utility). Each kWh your system produces first offsets home consumption; any excess exported earns a kWh credit at the full retail rate, applied to your next bill.
Credits roll forward month to month throughout the year without expiration — until the annual cash-out.
Annual Cash-Out (May Billing Cycle)
After the May billing cycle, Pennsylvania utilities are required by law to cash out any remaining NEM credits. You will receive either a check or a credit to your account for the balance — but at the "Price to Compare" rate, which is approximately half the retail rate (supply + transmission, excluding distribution).
This means credits that roll from summer into winter are fully valuable, but any leftover balance after May is paid out at a significantly reduced rate. Plan accordingly — the ideal scenario is consuming most of your accumulated credits before the May reset.
Competitive Electric Suppliers — Important Warning
Pennsylvania utilities are not required to provide net metering credits if you receive electricity supply from a third-party Competitive Electric Supplier. If you switched your supply service and receive a separate supply bill, your solar credits may not apply to those supply and transmission charges.
If this applies to you, contact your distribution utility to return to full-service electricity to maximize your net metering value.
SRECs
Pennsylvania solar customers are eligible to earn and sell Solar Renewable Energy Certificates (SRECs) via the PJM-GATS registry. Venture Home handles registration for all eligible customer-owned systems. Each 1,000 kWh your system produces generates one SREC, which can be sold on the open market.
Rhode Island Utility Guide
1-to-1 Net Metering with ConnectedSolutions Battery Incentive
Key Takeaways
Venture Home enrolls all Rhode Island customers in the Net Metering program
1-to-1 net metering credits roll forward indefinitely; optional cash-out at Last Resort Supply rate
REG: Fixed 20-year per-kWh payment as a feed-in tariff (no traditional net metering)
Renewable Energy Fund (REF) grants of up to $5,000 available — Venture Home applies on your behalf
ConnectedSolutions battery program available for additional incentive income
Utility: Rhode Island Energy (formerly National Grid RI)
Net Metering Program
Rhode Island Energy offers 1-to-1 net metering for customer-owned solar systems. Each kWh your system exports earns a credit at nearly the full retail rate — you lose only the renewable energy and energy efficiency charges (approximately 2.2–2.5 cents per kWh).
Excess credits roll forward indefinitely on your account as dollar credits. Starting February 2024, you can optionally request a cash-out of accumulated credits at the lower Last Resort Service supply rate, or transfer credits to another account in your name.
You will still receive a monthly bill for fixed customer charges that cannot be offset by solar.
ConnectedSolutions — Battery Incentive
Rhode Island Energy's ConnectedSolutions program pays battery customers for reducing grid draw during peak demand periods.
Performance-based payment per average kW curtailed during dispatch events
Events are summer-weighted; the program does not call events during outages or in the two days before predicted severe weather
Enrollment is voluntary
More info: rienergy.com/ConnectedSolutions
RECs
Rhode Island solar customers are eligible for Class 1 NEPOOL-GIS RECs. Venture Home handles registration for eligible customer-owned systems.

Property Tax Exemption
Rhode Island exempts the added value of solar installations from property tax assessment. Installing solar can increase your home's market value — in Rhode Island, that increase will not raise your property taxes. No application is required; the exemption is applied automatically when your property is assessed.
Sales Tax Exemption
Solar equipment and installation costs in Rhode Island are exempt from the 7% state sales tax. The exemption is applied at point of purchase — no action required. On a typical $17,000 system, this saves approximately $1,190 upfront.
Rhode Island Renewable Energy Fund (REF) Grant
You may be eligible for a one-time upfront grant from the Rhode Island Renewable Energy Fund, administered by the Rhode Island Office of Energy Resources (OER). Venture Home handles the application process as part of your installation — confirm with your project manager whether the program has available funding at the time of your installation.

articles.title: Delaware Solar Incentives
question_aliases: What solar incentives are available in Delaware?

content_chunks.content:
Delaware
Incentive
Key Details
PA SREC Market Access
Delaware solar owners can participate in the PA AEC market
No State Income Tax on Solar
Delaware has no state income tax, so no solar tax credit applies
No Sales Tax
Delaware has no sales tax — automatic savings on all purchases
Property Tax
All personal property in DE is generally exempt from property tax
Pennsylvania SREC (AEC) Market Access
While Delaware does not operate its own SREC market, Delaware solar owners are eligible to register their systems in Pennsylvania's Alternative Energy Credit (AEC) market. This allows you to earn AECs for every MWh your system produces and sell them to PA utilities and electricity suppliers meeting the Pennsylvania AEPS.
AEC prices fluctuate with market conditions. Venture Home can assist with GATS registration to enable AEC creation for Delaware customers.
No Sales Tax
Delaware has no general state sales tax on any purchases — so solar equipment and installation are automatically free from sales tax. This is not a solar-specific incentive but represents real upfront savings compared to neighboring states.
Property Tax
Delaware generally does not impose property taxes on personal property, and in practice solar panels installed on residential properties are treated as personal property equipment. As a result, solar installations in Delaware typically do not increase property taxes, though this can vary by county. Consult your local assessor for your specific situation.

articles.title: Delaware Utility Guide
question_aliases: How does net metering work in Delaware?

content_chunks.content:
Delaware Utility Guide
1-to-1 Net Metering with Annual True-Up + SREC Program
Key Takeaways
1-to-1 net metering — credits roll forward in kWh
Annual true-up: you choose your reset month once (March or April recommended); unused credits expire — no cash payout
Green Energy Program offers upfront rebates (Delmarva Power: up to $6,000)
SREC program via SREC Delaware/PJM-GATS: ~$30/SREC for years 1–10, $10/SREC years 11–25
No state sales tax in Delaware — solar equipment savings baked in
Utilities: Delmarva Power, Delaware Electric Cooperative (DEC), DEMEC municipal utilities
Net Metering Policy
Delaware requires all major utilities — Delmarva Power, Delaware Electric Cooperative, and DEMEC municipal members — to provide 1-to-1 net metering for residential systems. Credits are tracked in kWh, not dollars.
Each kWh your system produces that exceeds home consumption is credited to your account. You draw credits back down when production is insufficient (nights, winter). Fixed monthly charges (meter fees) must be paid in cash and cannot be offset by kWh credits.
Annual True-Up
Net metering credits reset at the end of your chosen 12-month period. Unlike some states, Delaware does not pay out unused credits — any remaining kWh credits simply expire. You can choose your annual true-up month one time; you may change it once after that.
Our recommendation: Choose March or April as your true-up month. This timing lets you accumulate summer and fall solar credits and draw them down through winter, maximizing the kWh you consume before the reset.
Green Energy Program (Upfront Rebates)
Delaware's Green Energy Program provides upfront rebates through participating utilities:
Delmarva Power: ~$0.70/watt, up to $6,000 — application handled by Venture Home as part of installation
Delaware Electric Cooperative: $0.50/watt for first 5 kW, $0.20/watt thereafter
Note: Green Energy Program rebates are applied directly to your installation cost
SREC Program
Delaware's SREC Delaware program allows customer-owned solar systems to earn and sell Solar Renewable Energy Certificates (SRECs) via an annual auction process. One SREC is generated for every 1,000 kWh (1 MWh) your system produces.
Years 1–10: ~$30/SREC (price determined at auction — recent prices have held steady)
Years 11–25: $10/SREC flat rate
Submit monthly production meter readings through the SREC Delaware online portal (Venture Home provides setup guidance)
Payments are on a 2-month delay from production
Example: An 8 kW system generating ~10 SRECs/year earns roughly $300/year in years 1–10.
Note: Delaware is actively studying potential net metering policy changes (Senate Joint Resolution No. 1, January 2025). We will keep customers informed if significant changes are made.
Maryland Utility Guide
1-to-1 Net Metering with Annual Cash-Out + Active SREC Market
Key Takeaways
1-to-1 net metering — credits roll forward month to month
Annual cash-out in April: any remaining credits paid at average annual commodity rate (~$0.04–$0.07/kWh) or carried forward indefinitely (your choice as of 2025)
Active SREC market via PJM-GATS — Venture Home handles registration
Property and sales tax exemptions
Utilities: BGE, Pepco, Potomac Edison, Delmarva Power MD, SMECO, Choptank Electric
Net Metering Policy
Maryland requires all major utilities to provide 1-to-1 net metering. Each kWh your system produces first offsets home consumption; any excess earns a kWh credit at the full retail rate. Credits roll forward month to month.
Annual Cash-Out (April)
Each April, Maryland utilities reconcile net metering accounts. As of 2025, you have two options for any remaining credits:
Cash out: receive payment at the average annual commodity rate, typically $0.04–$0.07/kWh (significantly below retail)
Carry forward indefinitely: keep credits rolling on your account with no expiration
For most customers, carrying credits forward is the better financial choice. Only consider requesting cash-out if you're moving or have an unusual situation.
SRECs
Maryland has an active SREC market through PJM-GATS. Customer-owned solar systems earn one SREC per 1,000 kWh (1 MWh) of production. SRECs can be sold to utilities and electricity suppliers who must meet Maryland's Renewable Portfolio Standard.
SREC prices in Maryland fluctuate based on market supply and demand. Venture Home handles PJM-GATS registration for all eligible customer-owned systems. Once registered, SRECs are typically sold through an aggregator or broker.
Tax Exemptions
Property tax: Solar systems are exempt from property tax assessment statewide
Sales tax: Solar equipment is fully exempt from Maryland's 6% sales tax
Washington D.C. Utility Guide
1-to-1 Net Metering + Among the Highest SREC Values in the Country
Key Takeaways
1-to-1 net metering — credits roll forward month to month
Year-end: credits expire December 31, but Pepco pays out remaining balance (at generation-only rate, ~8–9¢/kWh) if over $25
DC SRECs are among the most valuable in the US — prices fluctuate but have recently traded around $400/SREC
No DC-specific battery incentives currently
Utility: Pepco (sole electric utility in DC)
Net Metering Policy
Pepco provides 1-to-1 net metering throughout DC. Each kWh your system exports earns a kWh credit at the full retail rate. Credits roll forward month to month through December 31.
At year-end, credits expire — but Pepco pays out any remaining balance greater than $25 at the generation-only rate (approximately $0.088/kWh as of early 2025, which excludes transmission costs). This is lower than retail but ensures you're not simply losing credits.
You will still receive a monthly fixed charge (~$18) that cannot be offset by solar credits.
DC SRECs — Exceptional Value
DC has one of the strongest SREC markets in the country, driven by DC's ambitious Renewable Portfolio Standard (100% renewable energy by 2032 with aggressive solar carve-outs) and high Alternative Compliance Payments that utilities pay if they fall short.
1 SREC is generated per 1,000 kWh (1 MWh) of solar production
DC SREC prices fluctuate based on market conditions — recent prices have hovered around $400/SREC, though this can vary
A typical 8 kW system generating ~10 MWh/year earns ~$4,000/year in SREC income
SRECs are valid for 3 years from date of generation
By contrast, Maryland SRECs trade at roughly $50–$60. If you're a Maryland customer served by Pepco and your home is on DC feeder lines (common in border areas of Montgomery and Prince George's Counties), you may be eligible for DC's SREC market — contact us to confirm.
Venture Home registers all eligible DC customer-owned systems in the DC SREC market. Once registered, SRECs are typically sold through a broker who pays you directly.
State Tax Incentives
DC does not currently offer a state-level solar tax credit or battery-specific incentive. The primary financial drivers in DC are net metering and the SREC program, which together provide exceptional economics for solar customers.

articles.title: Maryland Solar Incentives
question_aliases: What solar incentives are available in Maryland?

content_chunks.content:
Maryland
Incentive
Key Details
Maryland Solar Access Program
Up to $7,500 grant — income-qualified (≤150% state median income)
MD SREC Market
Earn and sell SRECs; current market ~$50–55/SREC
Property Tax Exemption
100% exemption, state and local — no action required
Sales Tax Exemption
100% — no sales tax on solar equipment
Local Credits
Select counties offer additional one-time property tax credits
Maryland Solar Access Program (MEA)
The Maryland Energy Administration (MEA) offers grants to income-eligible Maryland homeowners through the Maryland Solar Access Program (MSAP). Established by the Brighter Tomorrow Act of 2024, this program replaced the prior Residential Clean Energy Rebate.
Grant amount: Up to $7,500, calculated at $750 per kilowatt (kW) of DC solar capacity installed.
Income eligibility: Household income must not exceed 150% of the Maryland statewide area median income (approximately $128,430 for a 1-person household, $183,375 for a 4-person household in FY25).
Application: Two-step process — Step 1 reserves your funds before installation; Step 2 verifies installation is complete. Applications are first-come, first-served and must be submitted prior to installation. You must use a contractor on the MEA Participating Contractor List (Venture Home is registered).
Status: FY26 program is open for applications as of July 2025 — contact your Venture Home project manager to check current availability.
MEA Maryland Solar Access Program: energy.maryland.gov
Maryland SREC Market
Maryland's Renewable Portfolio Standard (RPS) requires utilities to source a percentage of electricity from solar. Solar owners earn one SREC for every MWh their system produces over the first 15 years, and can sell those SRECs to utilities on the Maryland SREC market.
Current Maryland SREC market prices are approximately $50–55 per SREC (the Solar Alternative Compliance Payment, or SACP, is set at $55 for 2025 and declines gradually to $22.50 by 2030). An average 8 kW system producing 9 MWh/year can earn approximately $450–500 annually in SREC income, totaling an estimated $3,500–4,000 over 15 years.
Venture Home registers your system in PJM-EIS GATS so your SRECs are created and available for sale. You can engage a broker to sell your SRECs — Venture Home can point you to reputable options.
Property Tax Exemption
Maryland provides a 100% state and local real property tax exemption for solar energy systems used to heat or cool a structure, provide hot water, or generate electricity. This applies to both residential and commercial properties. Your solar installation will not increase your property tax assessment — no action required.
In addition, certain counties offer supplemental local property tax credits (these are one-time credits, separate from the statewide exemption):
Anne Arundel County: Up to $2,500 one-time property tax credit
Harford County: Up to $2,500 per solar device, $5,000 per property per fiscal year
Prince George's County: Up to $5,000 alternative energy tax credit (also available to lessees)
Contact your county tax authority or your Venture Home project manager for current program details and application requirements.
Sales Tax Exemption
Maryland exempts solar energy equipment (panels, inverters, mounting, battery storage) and solar water heaters from state sales and use tax. The exemption is automatic at point of purchase — on a $20,000 system, this saves approximately $1,200 (6% rate).

Pepco provides 1-to-1 net metering throughout DC. Each kWh your system exports earns a kWh credit at the full retail rate. Credits roll forward month to month through December 31.
At year-end, credits expire — but Pepco pays out any remaining balance greater than $25 at the generation-only rate (approximately $0.088/kWh as of early 2025, which excludes transmission costs). This is lower than retail but ensures you're not simply losing credits.
You will still receive a monthly fixed charge (~$18) that cannot be offset by solar credits.
DC SRECs — Exceptional Value
DC has one of the strongest SREC markets in the country, driven by DC's ambitious Renewable Portfolio Standard (100% renewable energy by 2032 with aggressive solar carve-outs) and high Alternative Compliance Payments that utilities pay if they fall short.
1 SREC is generated per 1,000 kWh (1 MWh) of solar production
DC SREC prices fluctuate based on market conditions — recent prices have hovered around $400/SREC, though this can vary
A typical 8 kW system generating ~10 MWh/year earns ~$4,000/year in SREC income
SRECs are valid for 3 years from date of generation
By contrast, Maryland SRECs trade at roughly $50–$60. If you're a Maryland customer served by Pepco and your home is on DC feeder lines (common in border areas of Montgomery and Prince George's Counties), you may be eligible for DC's SREC market — contact us to confirm.
Venture Home registers all eligible DC customer-owned systems in the DC SREC market. Once registered, SRECs are typically sold through a broker who pays you directly.
State Tax Incentives
DC does not currently offer a state-level solar tax credit or battery-specific incentive. The primary financial drivers in DC are net metering and the SREC program, which together provide exceptional economics for solar customers.

articles.title: Washington DC Solar Incentives
question_aliases: What solar incentives are available in Washington DC?

content_chunks.content:
Washington, D.C. Incentive
Key Details
DC SREC Market
Some of the highest SREC values in the US — prices fluctuate, recently ~$400/SREC
Property Tax Exemption
Solar added value exempt from DC property taxes
Solar for All
Income-qualified program for low-income DC residents
DC Solar Renewable Energy Credits (SRECs)
The District of Columbia has one of the most valuable SREC markets in the United States. DC's Renewable Portfolio Standard (RPS) has aggressive solar carve-outs and steep Alternative Compliance Payments, which drives high SREC demand and prices.
DC SREC prices fluctuate based on market conditions. Recent trading prices have hovered around $400 per SREC — significantly higher than most neighboring state markets.
An average 7–8 kW DC system producing ~9 MWh/year can earn approximately $3,500+ annually at current prices. Long-term revenue depends on market conditions.
Venture Home registers your system to earn and track DC SRECs through PJM-EIS GATS. You retain the RECs and sell them through a broker or directly to buyers. Market prices can change — ask your project manager about current pricing at the time of your installation.
Property Tax Exemption
Washington, D.C. exempts the added value of solar installations from property tax assessments. Installing solar panels will not increase your DC property tax bill. The exemption is applied automatically.
